captions.text: I&#39;ve got a new book available on Audible.com from December 9th
It&#39;s called Existentially Challenged
and it&#39;s a hilarous supernatural murder mystery
set in a world getting to grips with the british government
having declassifed the existance of magic.
To answer all of the anticipated questions
Yes, it&#39;s a sequel to Differently Morphous.
Yes, it&#39;s only an audiobook at the moment.
Yes, it&#39;s read by me.
Yes, a print verison will be out next year sometime.
And no, I don&#39;t still wear this hat in real life.
*INTRO MUSIC*
It was with mixed feelings that I went into Halo Infinite.
On the one hand we all know this series is never going to bloody
end so I appreciate the title being up front about it,
but on the other I&#39;ve never really gotten on with Halo
as a franchise.
I&#39;ve never understood what&#39;s going on in the overarching plot.
I asked Nick the Escapist editor and professional Halo liking person
to summarize it for me and he was all like &quot;Oh the forerunners
created the precursors and the prometheans-&quot;
Okay, stop listing words that all mean the same thing.
Start at the basics.
Why is humanity at war with the Covenant?
&quot;Because the Covenant worship the forerunners but are jealous
that the forerunners favoured humanity because-&quot;
&quot;Bastards hate humans, kill all the bastards.&quot;
GOT IT.
Should&#39;ve led with that.
I&#39;ve said before Bungie IPs are 90% setting and 10% plot so
&quot;Bastards hate humans, kill all the bastards&quot; is really all you need
for the moment to moment experience.
And having gained that insight, I appreciated Halo Infinite more
than I expected.
Because the story seems to have a conscious &quot;back to basics&quot;
approach.
You know that whole plot the last few games were setting up with
Cortana turning into the big baddy? Well that&#39;s all in the bin.
Halo Infinite starts in the aftermath of Cortana already having been
sorted out as a new and bigger bunch of bastards show up who
hate humans more than any previous bastards,
wiping out the human forces and leaving Master Chief for dead.
They&#39;re called the Banished, so let&#39;s just add that to the
ever-expanding list of Halo entities named The and an ominous
word.
After Chief gets discovered in space and reactivated for the
umpteenth time he has to go down to a new Halo ring to prevent
the Banished from reactivating the Auditorium on behalf of the
Harbinger because - a ta ta ta ta, Halo.
Sorry, I meant to say, bastards hate humans, kill all the bastards.
Thank you! I will! And since Halo Infinite takes influence from open
world shooters, there is a quite inexhaustible supply of bastards
because what else&#39;re you gonna do in post-ending fuckabouts
mode. I say &quot;takes influence from open worlds&quot; rather than flat out
&quot;is an open world.&quot;
Certainly there&#39;s an open world in it.
One that showed up late to the final exam for open worlds and had
to hastily scribble out an assignment that it turned out was from
last year&#39;s syllabus.
It&#39;s like some board of directors heard about this open world thing
the kids like and told market research to compile a powerpoint.
And they came back with &quot;copy pasted towers and base assaults as
far as the eye can see.&quot;
And besides when it forces you to climb four copy pasted towers
spread out around the map before it lets you into the next part,
the overall plot doesn&#39;t really engage with the open world.
Completing the optional base assaults or side activities doesn&#39;t give
you any significant edge in standard gameplay, since the most
powerful pew pew laser guns are always conveniently strewn
around every combat and boss arena like minifridges in hotel
rooms and none of the optional crap you can do makes them pew
pew any harder. For you see while Halo is flirting with open worlds,
it will never stray from its true love: shiny corridors.
Its eye might have briefly been drawn by the open world&#39;s
sensuous curves but its love for shiny corridors is the kind of
unyielding emotional bedrock on which contented marriages
are built. So the open world sections are separated by plot
missions where you complete inescapable sequences of enclosed
arenas connected by shiny corridors now you&#39;re done fooling about
with your open world hussy. And I feel Halo Infinite should&#39;ve
picked a lane. Why not go full Breath of the Wild? Maybe Ms. Open
World can&#39;t offer stability but it might&#39;ve livened up your dull middle
age, Halo. Trying to talk the missus into this undignified polyamory
is only going to look bad in divorce court.
But with an open world comes a need for traversal mechanics,
most Halo vehicles flip over if they drive over anything larger than a
chocolate raisin and the terrain is usually about as even as a
section of your grandmother&#39;s upper thigh served with crinkle cut
chips, so to counterbalance all that, Master Chief gets a fucking
hookshot. And I fucking love it. It&#39;s not as fast or as versatile as,
say, the Just Cause hookshot, probably because it has to haul
around the dump truck Master Chief is constantly wearing and all
the Mars bars secreted in the glove compartment, but there are
very few games that wouldn&#39;t be improved by a grappling hook.
Losing at Civilization wouldn&#39;t be so bad if I had the option of a
dignified exit. So I was hookshotting up to vantage points to
descend upon enemy bases, hookshotting into vehicles to hijack
them, and outside the open world, hookshotting my merry way
down shiny corridors to avoid wearing out Master Chief&#39;s plimsolls.
But for some reason the game seems to have mistaken this core
traversal mechanic for a gimmicky gadget. You have to unequip
the grappling hook to use deployable cover, dodge thrusters or see
enemies through walls-o-vision. So guess what three things
I never fucking used.
And never fucking needed. Deployable cover? I&#39;ll just hookshot
myself behind this bin. And why see enemies through walls when I
can just hookshot over the wall and look at them. What about
dodge thrusters? You can use them to outwit those incredibly
annoying charging berserker enemies. Or I could just hookshot
them in the face, which stuns them out of the charge, and with the
hookshot upgrades I can then deliver a powered melee strike that
launches them like Team Rocket and is a million times more fun
than any of Halo&#39;s standard range of nerf guns. The hookshot
became a central part of both combat and traversal so I&#39;d sooner
unequip Master Chief&#39;s armoured trousers. Never used anything
else or spent upgrade tokens on them, which is another nail in the
heart of the open world since finding upgrade tokens is one of the
only reasons to explore besides getting your cardio in. Still, the
hookshot might be all Halo needs to enhance its otherwise rather
stale combat, which is about as much as you&#39;d expect - lots of
enemies firing lots of glowing blobs and Master Chief occasionally
randomly exploding because you mistook an incoming very
dangerous glowing blob for one of the relatively harmless ones.
Alright fine since it&#39;s Christmas I&#39;ll say I&#39;ve had worse times with
shooters and I did appreciate the relative straightforwardness
of the plot - shoot all the bastards, big bastard is your new arch
nemesis basically because he declares himself such and nobody
else called dibs - but you might be disappointed if you have a long
term investment. I&#39;m gonna talk about the ending now so if
you don&#39;t want spoilers either stop watching or turn on the little
windscreen wipers on your face helmet. Not that there&#39;s some big
spoilable twist where Master Chief dramatically reveals himself to
be Tom Selleck. No, I just didn&#39;t want to spoil that there is no twist.
The game ends with a big fat return to status quo - Master Chief
gets a brand new factory reset non-psychotic soberly dressed
Cortana and declares his intention to keep killing all the bastards,
leaving me with a profound sense of &quot;Wow, twenty years and we&#39;ve
basically gone absolutely fucking nowhere, have we, Halo.&quot;
The only difference is Master Chief has a new hairy boyfriend.
The bearded pilot sidekick is the closest thing to a proper love
interest he&#39;s ever had. He has to be rescued about as often as
Princess Peach. Gives him a nice romantic cuddle near the end.
I ain&#39;t judging, I hope you&#39;ll be happy together, I just wonder if you
wouldn&#39;t get a more reciprocal relationship from slow dancing
with the air conditioner.
